docs.lead_paragraph: The Federal agency that oversees Medicare has decided to cover insulin infusion pumps, which help diabetics maintain blood sugar levels. But the approval covers only Type I, or juvenile diabetes, which affects just 5 percent to 10 percent of the estimated 16 million Americans with diabetes. In announcing its decision last week, the Health Care Financing Administration said the pumps, which deliver insulin through a catheter under the skin of the abdomen or hip, had not yet been shown to be effective for Type II, or adult-onset, diabetes, the most common form.
docs.abstract: Health Care Financing Administration, agency that oversees Medicare, decides to cover insulin infusion pumps, which help diabetics maintain blood sugar levels; coverage is limited to those with juvenile-onset diabetes; American Assn of Clinical Endocrinologists wants Medicare coverage for adult-onset diabetes patients also (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Six scientists have won prestigious Lasker awards for research into the brain, the development of a heart drug and discoveries about electrical signals in the body. The awards, to be presented Friday in New York, are administered by the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation.

headline.main: 6 Scientists Named as Winners of Lasker Awards

docs.abstract: Six scientists win prestigious Lasker awards for research into the brain, the development of a heart drug and discoveries about electrical signals in the body; awards are administered by Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They are called phthalates, and their job is to make plastic flexible so it can be used in tubes for blood transfusions, intravenous feeding and other life-support systems at hospitals and clinics around the world -- and in some children's toys. The trouble with these chemicals, some scientists and consumer advocates say, is that they may be dangerous: small amounts can leach into the bloodstream and have been shown in animal studies to cause cancer and other serious ailments. A small number of studies of human exposure suggest the possible presence of adverse effects as well, these critics say.

headline.main: A Debate Over Safety Of Softeners For Plastic

docs.abstract: Health professionals are divided on safety of phthalates, chemicals used to make plastic flexible for use in tubes for blood transfusions, intravenous feeding and other life-support systems at hospitals and clinics; some scientists and consumer advocates claim that small amounts of chemicals can leach into bloodstream and have been shown in animal studies to cause serious ailments; other scientists say phthalates are safe, and panel of scientists led by Dr C Everett Koop, former Surgeon General, backs that view; photos (M)
docs.snippet: They are called phthalates, and their job is to make plastic flexible so it can be used in tubes for blood transfusions, intravenous feeding and other life-support systems at hospitals and clinics around the world -- and in some children's toys.    ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Before your next hospital stay, you might want to ponder a question raised in last week's New England Journal of Medicine: Do the doctors and nurses on staff know their literature? Not medical literature. Just literature, of the type studied in English classes.

headline.main: Alas, Poor Doctors, They Read Too Little

docs.abstract: Letter to New England Journal of Medicine tells how a hospital patient was referred to psychiatrist because medical personnel did not recognize a comment of his as literary reference; concludes that medical personnel need broader education in humanities; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Before your next hospital stay, you might want to ponder a question raised in  last week's New England Journal of Medicine: Do the doctors and nurses on staff know their literature?     Not medical literature. Just literature, of the type studied in...

docs.lead_paragraph: When a famous person is found to have a serious and potentially fatal disease, it often serves as a wake-up call for the rest of us. Just as Nancy Reagan's breast cancer stimulated a rush for mammography, the recently diagnosed colon cancer of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court should jolt all women (and men) over 50 -- and some younger people as well -- to take advantage of the tests that can detect this disease while it is still curable, perhaps even before it has become cancer. Cancer of the colon and rectum is the second leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States, after lung cancer. It is also one of the most curable of cancers, but only if it is found in its early stages. Because colorectal cancer usually develops over many years and has a long precancerous stage, it can be detected early and even prevented if people adhere to recommended screening guidelines.

headline.main: Detecting Colon Cancer When It Is Curable

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on cancer of colon and rectum, second leading cause of cancer deaths in United States; says it is one of most curable of cancers, but only if found in early stages; says early state colorectal cancer is often silent disease, producing no symptoms, which is why periodic screening is so important; says contrary to popular opinion, disease hits women as well as men; graph (M)
docs.snippet: When a famous person is found to have a serious and potentially fatal disease, it often serves as a wake-up call for the rest of us. Just as Nancy Reagan's breast cancer stimulated a rush for mammography, the recently diagnosed colon cancer of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Pediatricians routinely counsel families about the importance of seat belts and smoke alarms. The American Academy of Pediatrics has long urged its members to add gun safety to that list -- but with less success, according to a new study reported in the September issue of the journal Pediatrics. The study finds that although pediatricians are willing to discuss the topic with their patients, they may not be good judges of which families need the information. In a survey of 66 pediatricians, virtually all agreed that they should discuss gun safety with families who own guns. But when it came to identifying those families, the doctors often missed the mark: when 169 of their patients were surveyed, it turned out that nearly a third of the families judged least likely to own guns reported owning at least one.

headline.main: Heeding Doctor's Orders on Gun Safety

docs.abstract: Journal Pediatrics includes new study showing that pediatricians are not regularly discussing gun safety with their patients; research suggests that when pediatricians do offer advice on gun safety, families are likely to take it seriously; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Pediatricians routinely counsel families about the importance of seat belts and smoke alarms. The American Academy of Pediatrics has long urged its members to add gun safety to that list -- but with less success, according to a new study reported in...

docs.lead_paragraph: I have a pretty odd sports closet. For one thing, it's an armoire. For another, it's crammed with gear more suited to mountains, rivers and ''Rocky'' than the asphalt playground known as New York City. Open it and out tumbles a rock-climbing harness, ski wax, a headlamp and a mouth guard. And that's just the first wave. But you'll never be bonked by bats, clubs or balls; I've never been much for conventional sports. Still, strangers always assume I play basketball.

headline.main: Taking to the Court for Basketball 101

docs.abstract: Article by Aimee Berg on Never Too Late, 8- and 10-week basketball courses offering novice, intermediate and advanced classes for women in New York City and Boston; diagrams (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When you hear hoofbeats, don't think of zebras. To doctors, the axiom is a call to focus on common ailments and not waste time on the exotic. But on those rare occasions when they do detect a zebra, doctors say they need to take extra steps in their investigation to make sure they have identified the right one.

headline.main: Encephalitis Outbreak Teaches an Old Lesson

docs.abstract: Lawrence K Altman column on finding that recent encephalitis outbreak is not St Louis virus, but closely related West Nile virus from Africa; says West Nile virus has never before been detected in Western Hemisphere, but Centers for Disease Control cannot be certain of that because Federal scientists never specifically checked for it in early outbreaks and individual cases; notes that CDC has led campaign against threat of new and emerging infections, and warned doctors to expect the exotic in infectious disease (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An onion a day could help keep osteoporosis away, suggests a study reported in the current issue of the journal Nature. Drs. Roman C. Muhlbauer and Feng Li of the University of Bern in Switzerland found that 14 vegetables common in the diet can significantly alter bone metabolism in rats and perhaps decrease the incidence of osteoporosis in humans. When male rats were fed one gram of dry onion per day, bone resorption -- the process in which calcium is released from bone stores, thereby weakening the bones -- was inhibited by 20 percent. That was slightly higher than the effect of a drug, calcitonin, at doses used to treat osteoporosis in women past menopause.

headline.main: Eat Your Onions and Save Your Bones

docs.abstract: Article in journal Nature suggests that good mix of vegetables in diet can alter bone metabolism and perhaps decrease incidence of osteoporosis; drawing (S)
